title: What are the hottest PhD research topics? - Quora

response.answer_text: The hot topic for a Ph.D. is the one for which you have a great deal of passion, and one that will sustain that passion beyond your Ph.D.. The subject matter may be something that you or someone close to you may have experienced personally. I completed my dissertation in 1990 and I am still very intrigued about the subjective experience of Alzheimer’s disease! My Mom was diagnosed with it at the age of 80 and it was the cause of her death at the age of 93. Having chaired many dissertations, the “hot topics” were always the ones that the student was personally invested in and often became the foundation for his or her career. I have led Alzheimer’s Support Groups for 25 years & have evaluated many patients with dementia. Let me share with you a few other “hot topics” which have become the basis of colleagues’ careers. “A Phenomenological Study of Early Stage Alzheimer’s Disease Patients” Lawrence J. Schulte, Ph.D. The Use of Service Dogs in Graduate School and in Organizational Settings. Maximizing Peak Performance in Professional Cyclists Racing. The Use of Hypnotherapy as Anesthesia and Pain Management. My colleague Dr. Eric Yelsa was Associate Professor at the University of Utah Medical Center where he was a member of the Department of Anesthesiology & taught hypnotherapy to medical residents for pain management. “Energy Balance Components and Body Fat in Prostate Cancer Survivors” Jackie Kiwata Dawson, Ph.D. Go inside and ask yourself one simple question: “What is the one thing that really intrigues me about ??? and will I want to continue to study it ten years from now?” Good luck!

Symbolism in ULYSSES, the rise of gun violence in US schools, the relationship between consumption and GDP, conflict between Montgomery and Patton in WWII, the connection between the Enlightenment and the American Revolution, How England’s failure to accept Leibnitz’ notation in favor of Newton’s hurt the growth of Mathematics in the UK for over a century. How America's Denial of science is hurting our future, the autobiographies of the Auden Generation. Wouldn’t it be nice if you knew a discipline for your PhD?

I think it’d be interesting to see a PhD dissertation examining the motivations and worldviews of people who ask the internet what they should write their PhD dissertations about. To me, it just seems like a really odd thing to do, because if you are going to find the motivation to write a dissertation, the topic needs be something that personally interests you, not some people on the internet who have never met you. I’m really curious what all these people are thinking, particularly what they think the PhD is supposed to be. I imagine this inquiry could find a place in some social science discipline.

Ordinarily, given a question like this I would hem and haw and clear my throat and buy time and eventually hedge by saying something about how there is no universal agreement about what is the hottest research topic. It depends who you ask, and what precisely you mean by hot, etc. However, these are not ordinary times. It seems clear that machine learning is the hottest research topic. It just is. It's such a hot topic it's kind of ridiculous. However, by the time you finish your PhD the hot topic might be something else.

Anything to do with human nature and its capacity for evil. Or, anybody who struggles for what is right, in the face of evil. It could be anyone obscure, as long as you can scrape up some information. I did mine on a space transportation system called a “rotating space elevator”. There is a seeming infinite amount of stuff to study about it, once you get into it. I have a theory that professors have 2 or 3 ideas just sitting around waiting for someone to work on them. So, to be serious, make this a New Years resolution: “I will talk to professors in my field of study about their ideas.” Happy New Year!

This question is much too broad. In order to give any meaningful answer, I would need to know your field of study. Then, I would need to know something of your interest, your focus, whether it was related to physical sciences or sociology, business or economics, and so on. Even if you could narrow it down to a discipline, such as environmental engineering it would be helpful. The best advice I received in selecting my dissertation topic was to pick something that I had a passion about, since it would consume most of my waking hours (and a lot of dream time) until I completed it. Upon completion, I would be considered an expert, so the dissertation would follow me around the rest of my life, too. So, the best idea is to first figure out what you’re studying.

Regardless of field (which I don’t see that you mention), the hottest topic is the one that you can produce a dissertation within, in a reasonable amount of time, with a reasonable amount of effort. Don’t pursue research during your doctorate because of trends; pursue a line of inquiry that you can complete. Save the cool stuff for after you defend a dissertation.

Q: What are some topics for a PhD thesis? A: Here’s my one: Research Question - “Why do some movies succeed, while most, don’t?” For the answer, in 100,000 words or less, see: My PhD Dissertation (free online) Here is the official PhD title, but for short I call it `the StoryAlity PhD’: (as the StoryAlity Theory of high RoI movies came out of the research) Communication, Creativity and Consilience in Cinema: A comparative study of the Top 20 Return-on-Investment (RoI) Movies and the doxa of Screenwriting‘ (Velikovsky 2016) Eg For more on the StoryAlity Theory of High RoI Movies, see the PhD blog: StoryAlity Also here is a list of another 100 x PhDs, (or Masters) in similar areas / on similar topics: StoryAlity #97 – Bio-cultural Dissertations
